title:      "Why Coding?"
date:       2019-05-10 07:34:14 +0000
permalink:  why_coding
---


Why Did I End Up Taking This Program??

Hey,

Why did I end up taking FlatIron FullStack Web Development program?
I tried the whole school thing a couple years ago after I graduated high school, and felt like it wasn't for me. I think looking back now, I needed more time to figure out who I was and what I enjoyed doing.

Since quitting community college in 2017, I decided I wanted to pursue a more artistic career (which I planned to pursue on my own.) Meanwhile, in order to support myself, I got a commercial driving license and began driving trucks.

![](https://www.160drivingacademy.com/img/pages/truck-driving-jobs.jpg)

On a side note, trucking was actually a really fun experience. Especially driving over the road. You basically live out in your truck, alone, and get to deliver cargo all over the country. You get to experience so much different areas of the U.S. and having lived in Los Angeles for most of my life, it was really eye opening to go to other parts of the U.S. You also meet a lot of cool people and see a lot of the countryside too.

Anyways, after a year or so of truck driving and trying to pursue what I wanted to learn on my own time, I felt like I had hit a wall. I just didn't know where I was supposed to be going or what I was supposed to be doing. I began looking into schools. I thought I needed some sort of stimulation. Something to keep my brain active besides what I did for work and the hobbies that I had.

So I began looking into community colleges around my area, and decided I was going to go back to community college and try to transfer to a four year university and get a bachelors in computer science or something. (I already had a bunch of credits built up and could have transfered after a couple semesters.) One thing that bothered me about going back to school was I already tried it and didn't enjoy it (the structure, the environment). But I thought maybe since I'm more mature now I'll be able to adapt to it more easily. And another thing that bothered me was, "what am I going to get out of going to school?" What is the exact cirriculum I will be taught? Will I be able to land a job after graduating? How much time is all of this going to take? Everything felt kind of like a guess.

![](data:image/jpeg;base64,)

But reluctantly, as I kind of felt directionless, I enrolled and was waiting to register for classes for the next semester.

Meanwhile, I began developing this huge rash that I'm pretty sure was caused by a bacterial infection. After months of trying to cure this problem with exercise, diet, and natural remedies, nothing worked and my rash as well as my digestion got worse. I finally decided to just pack up everything I had and leave home, as I thought maybe this condition is a result of stress from my current situation and also leaving home and living on my own was something I had been planning to do for a while now. All of this, me moving out, led to me discovering coding bootcamps.

![](https://i.pinimg.com/236x/10/ff/a4/10ffa4ccb09a7ef2d7f95f08ed21d1d8--outdoor-signage-desert-life.jpg)

Shortly after I set up base in Tucson, when I was looking into the local community college, I saw an ad about an online coding bootcamp, Lambda. It sounded like the perfect thing. Learning on my own time, learning on my own with also a little bit of structure, an exact cirriculum of what I was going to be learning, a career services department, and much more. Then shortly after looking into more coding bootcamps I found out about FlatIron and the rest is history!
